TL;DR: Solid 8/10 Main Game

Pros:
-Fantastic lore/world building
-Fantastic gameplay
-Huge world with things to do
-Great graphics/art direction
-Phenomenal soundtrack 
-Easy to get into for casual gamers, with plentiful options to make the game significantly easier

Cons:
-PC stuttering caused by shader compilation
-Certain bosses reward good RNG for a run instead of only outplaying them, however every boss is beatable with pure skill alone even if the boss uses their hardest/cheesiest moves. For example beating Malenia felt more like getting a good run than out-skilling her,
-World is vast but does not reward exploration for your specific build (i.e. there's no point in exploring if you already have a build in mind with specific talismans, etc.). Basically if there's nothing you need in a certain area then there's no point going there except for leveling purposes.
-Final boss of the main game is one of the worst main bosses

My Build:
-Melee only strength/stagger build with a two-handed colossal great sword, lion's claw, talismans that boost this playstyle, no summons, no cheesing bosses

Before I get into the negatives, I want to be very clear: this is one of my favorite games ever. I am a huge fan of the 2018 GoW, and this game actually improves on it in nearly every way. I wish that I could be writing a positive review right now, because this game absolutely deserves it... on console.

I bought the steam port the second it came out, and ever since, it has been fundamentally broken. I have no idea why most other reviewers aren't commenting on this, but this port is unplayable as it stands. I can repeatedly cause it to crash to desktop simply by looking at the in-game menus. If you want to read the in game lore, the game will crash the second you select any other item than the one it initially opened on, eg. Kvasir's Poems. The game also crashes during certain fights seemingly at random. And all of this will occur after closing the game and reopening to play later from your last save, which is a very normal thing to do.

I am running the game on an asus zephyrus laptop, with a 3080 gpu, as well as 8gb of vram. I am well within the bounds of recommended specs, and run intensive games all the time with no problems whatsoever. I have tried almost every combination of settings, both in and out of the game, but to no avail. I have scoured what little there is online, and amazingly, turning it off and on again doesn't fix an in-game bug, or bugs.

I have to imagine that all the good reviews are from people who haven't picked up this game since the first time opening it, or who have only played it on console. When this bug, or bugs, is fixed, I will immediately come back and edit this review to be glowing. But in the meantime, I encourage everyone to stay far away until it is fixed, and play the console version instead.

Firstly, just to get this out of the way, I've got a beastly PC running it on max settings and I never had any performance issues so I can't speak much to that. This review will be solely on the gameplay and what I like and dislike about it.

Like:
-The realistic feel of city expansion and district manipulation. Civ always felt too abstract and board-game like especially civ 6. This game introduces a level of depth that's very pleasing to toy around with.
-The details of buildings, cities, with little people and units walking around and being able to zoom very far in to see a living world that makes you feel like youre actually playing through history.  It's a step civ has never taken and I always wished they would.
-The core gameplay loop of analyzing production chains, making choices to suit your city's needs, optimizing, crafting, etc. It scratches an itch the city builder and anno enjoyer side of me finds very pleasing. Toying with these systems to get a desired outcome is very satisfying to do.

Neutrals
-Leader variety is nice, giving us 36 options from the beginning is a lot more variety than I expected. But a lot of them just feel weird. First playthrough is Copernicus of poland, which is cool, I guess, but also kind of... odd?
-The act-end cullings, this is... idk. I praised the game for its commitment to actually feeling like playing through history before but this mechanic really goes straight against that. empires randomly falling at the end of each act with the others able to scoop up their land? Kinda cool, could take it or leave it.
-Diplomacy, AI, Religion, etc. None of these systems are particularly fleshed out but I would encourage people to remember the "base" versions of games like Civ and Stellaris when they were first released without any DLC and how barebones those felt compared to how you can play them today. I think ara delivers a sufficient amount of content for several playthroughs.

Bad:
-The UI is just not very useful. It takes an ungodly amount of clicks to do something as simple as giving a farm a plow or heavy plow.
-Resource & Crafting management: I really enjoy the resource management this game gives and the ability one has to tweak productions, but especially in the late game it becomes a very tiring aspect as you have to navigate the sheer volume of stuff your empire produces. The game is in desperate need of some kind of automation or settings changes to make this more friendly on the player and not so tiresome. Like plows simply being auto doled out to farms in need. I think my biggest issue with this part of the game is just how dramatically it slows the overall pace down.

Overall, I'm probably going to keep playing Ara for a little while at least. I'm eager to see if Oxide and Microsoft enable modding and what directions they take the game in with future DLC. I think if you like 4x you'll probably enjoy playing this game.

+-1000 hours on CIV VI and cumulatively +-1000 hours on other similar games, and many more gameplay hours with city-builders and all types of strategy games. My opinion is as follows:

ARA is a disorganized, slow, unnecessarily complex, chaotic, infuriating, patience-demanding MESS!

I will first give my score on a couple of factors that I took in mind and which I deem important for such a game, out of 10. Of course, the high cost of the game is something that largely affected my opinion in the analysis and score-giving of the following factors.

Graphics and UI: 7/10 (randomly detailed, randomly not - UI/icons etc hide the charm... detailed icons, huge icons, many icons... I'd go for a colored AOE IV icon version)
Performance: 4/10 (crashes; click-bugs; freezes; generally patience-demanding)
Acts/ages/eras: 2/10 (horrible era system - eras are only namely mentioned and the game is 3 acts - eras; the most significant thing is research and it feels incomplete and sketchy - no immersion at all - bad copy of CIV)
Maps: 3/10 (no real variety; I tried 4 randomly generated maps with different settings. Territories look dull and boring, the textures are detailed but there is no real variety, no real color, no real elevation and cliffs - mountains are simply impassable - Humankind maps look better, CIV VII maps more promising, too)
Leaders: 1/10 (very cartoonishly out of context, like you put Mr. Bean in a SAW movie - they 100% copied CIV VI here, no doubt)
Expansion: 8/10 (I do like the city cap, and territories)
Wars: 5/10 (nothing special, the AI is super dumb and will just attack for expansion till you literally wanna go play something else or quit gaming altogether)
Religion: 1/10 (no game-changer, it feels weird)

It's an attempt to create a complex game that combines Sid Meier's Civilization games, Anno and Humankind without any utility to actually apply that complexity efficiently. Full of performance issues and bugs, sometimes you have to click 3 and 4 and even 10 times to get something done. The materials, products and the buildings that make them are all over the map and the tiny, hyper-realistic circular icons that appear together are VERY difficult to distinguish from each other, so you end up clicking everywhere to find the building that you need, hoping, with your intuition and on your patience limits, that it's the one you had been looking for.

The difficulty settings are not clear. I am trying the easiest setting in an attempt to get familiar with the game while also being eager to reach the final era because I love future eras in these games. However, the easiest setting is weird. In one game, the AI was a potato, I suppose because the map was bigger so they didn't need to conquer me. In fact, I was 2 times stronger than the second AI. I gave the game up because I was overwhelmed by the production/building (and what not) UI chaos. Also, and I stress it - my device is pretty fast, the game has very annoying performance issues. No matter the settings I tried, ultra settings and lower settings give the exact same result in performance. It's just slow in average, with annoying bugs, like the game doesn't understand "left click" sometimes.

I see people comparing it to CIV games, and I did mention it, because the basis of the idea is similar to CIV, of course. Despite that, it's nothing like CIV VI for example, but not in a good way, because although the idea is refreshing, you end up having to deal with production all the time instead of actually enjoying the game. It's like Old World, but more complex and broken/chaotic.

There is no clear production line. There is no clear purpose. Everything revolves around "prestige", which is like oxygen for your empire-civ-town-village-cottage or whatever you managed to keep after being attacked 25 million times on "easiest". Am I an inexperienced player and should just suck up the wars thing? No, because it doesn't happen organically, the AI will attack you BY DEFAULT if they have no more space to expand, instead of making any attempt at trading (which is certainly not a game changer either). 

The graphics? Of course, pretty beautiful, but with ALL THE MENUS you are almost unable to see anything anyway, and you need to see the yields, the borders, the huge icons for units (that render them almost invisible as well), you end up with no actual space to see those "beautiful" graphics. Although mind you, I was looking at the buildings carefully and houses look very weird; some nice houses appear that follow the trends of each age, but then suddenly you see something like unfinished CONCRETE boxes with roofs all over the place, that make no sense at all - they look like slums, minus the high density (pun intended). 

To sum it up:

The game is WAY too expensive for its current quality (day of release). It's a sugarcoated early-access game and we all had to pay them the money because they obviously invested a lot in it and people had to get paid, but it's NOT A FINISHED GAME. It's an early-access game, and we have been deceived. However, I do understand the developers/beneficiaries' side, because we live in modern capitalism. I think by giving it an early-access phase, the game would have gotten way better ratings. You can't make people expect a finished game and give THIS, because when you will want to invest more on it, people will turn their backs on you. There are so many developers making new games nowadays, you can't just go and release an unfinished game for 60 euros (in my case).

Do I like the game? Yes, but it needs so much work. And start by firing whoever had the idea for this horrible UI, because the performance-killing detailed graphics aren't even visible anymore with that interface.

Does a lot of cool new things, and super immersive graphics and designs on the cities as they grow naturally, really want to keep playing but the performance issue was becoming untenable... hopefully issues like vsync and shadows can be ironed out and the game will live up to it's immense potential.

review_text:
As a hardcore ROTK fan, this is probably one of the top three worse ROTK games. 

The battle mechanics are way worse. They did some weird thing where you can only give an order or series of orders during your turn that plays out in the battle phase. Sounds ok at first, but you'll soon find units sitting around and waiting after destroying an enemy unit while 4 hexes away another enemy army is beating up your ally. It's all based around the AI settings that you put forth, but the AI is too simplistic to be intuitive, or even show some semblance of intelligence.

You'll find everything is based around AI. All you do as a ruler is use excel with a poor UI. Duels? Only watching as two dudes just hit each other. Debates? What's that? Marriage/sworn brothers system, 10,000g for a slight buff in battle and loyalty.  Don't even get me started on their new event system.

There's not room for roleplay or to immerse yourself. Just play ROTK 8, 10, or 11, they are just more in depth and provide more. 

There is no desire for me to develop my generals. They provide you tons of skills to train your generals. But it's just a chore and takes so much time for no benefit. Maybe if I had some sort of attachment to my generals in any shape or form, I would. But it's all just stats.

For Christ's sake, ROTK4 had more depth in it and that was a SNES game on 16 bits. I don't know who they are trying to entertain with this game.

game_name: ROMANCE OF THE THREE KINGDOMS XIV
review_text:
Inability to Promote Officers During Battle: It's frustrating that we can't promote officers while they're in battle. We're forced to wait until everyone is back at base before promoting them.

Difficulty Employing Characters Like Guan Yu, Zhang Fei, and Cai Yan: Despite numerous attempts, we're unable to employ characters like Guan Yu, Zhang Fei, and Cai Yan. We keep receiving alerts that they're unemployed, yet they continue to reject our offers.

Uninteresting Battle Duels: The battle duels lack excitement. I remember a version of ROTK where duels were engaging, with buttons to press for counters and other actions. Incorporating such features would greatly enhance the gameplay experience.

Lackluster Area/City Government Mechanics: The mechanics for managing area and city governments are dull. It simply involves assigning an officer and then repeatedly sending idle officers out for employment until orders are depleted.

Stagnant Background Music (BGM): The BGM remains unchanged from many versions ago, which contributes to a feeling of stagnation in the game's overall experience.

Overall, the game feels more like a remastered version of an older ROTK installment rather than a significant improvement. Despite advancements in graphics, fundamental gameplay elements have seen little to no enhancement over the years.
